channel.title: Redundant Arguments
channel.description:
I've been trying to get the client into a re compilable form. Throw wrappers, nots and a whole bunch of other stuff I've already dealt with. What I'm stuck on is the redundant arguments and control field.
For the control field I'll simply hook the static field in the client that is read so many times and who's value is true. Its relatively easy to then rip out whatever depends on it.
For the arguments however things are a little harder. For one they are used everywhere and there isn't a specific pattern for what they do. They certainly don't have simple things like the first index of the local variable table (there isn't any).
So how do I remove these arguments?

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“cartridges, post:10, topic:210319”]Well, actually, there’s a pattern to the chaos.

int i = ((byte) (63 / b) * 2);

Etc can be regex’ed and removed.[/quote]sure, but regexing bytecode is gay

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

mmmm… infinite loooooppppp…

Sorry Speljohan for the copy cat but I couldn’t resist.

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:7, topic:210319”]find whatever calls those functions?

find the range that a legitimate value can have, that way when it is a dummy call, it is easy to identify[/quote]That’s a pretty neat idea really. Also, generally they use the same dummy values when calling a method with a dummy argument over and over again.

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

find whatever calls those functions?

find the range that a legitimate value can have, that way when it is a dummy call, it is easy to identify

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

The problem is the recursive ones. No amount of computing the values on the stack will get around a method calling itself.

I was hopping somebody had encountered this problem before and could help me with a generic solution.

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

The dummy arguments have a number of patterns they can follow, it’s pretty simple to remove the non-recursive ones. One of the most common scenarios is the following:

public static void doShit(int a, byte b) { stuffHere(); int i = ((byte) (63 / b) * 2); otherStuffHere(a); }

Simply check if the newly created local variable is used, if not remove argument.

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

BAsh:

I already compute the stack and local variables at the expense of my memory.

then what is your problem?

Read full topic

item.title: Redundant Arguments
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Dynamic would be possible but way too much hard work and code that is rarely executed would not be analyzed.

I already compute the stack and local variables at the expense of my memory.

Read full topic

For the control field I’ll simply hook the static field in the client that is read so many times and who’s value is true. Its relatively easy to then rip out whatever depends on it.
